facts.text: Kalooram Todi had two sons: Govindram (d. January 1943) and Gangaprasad (d. 1933). Govindram's son Nandlal (d. 9-12-1945). Gangaprasad's line leads to Bachhulal.
After Kalooram Todi's death, Govindram and Gangaprasad constituted a joint Hindu family owning property including Seth Govindram Sugar Mills at Mahidpur Road.
In 1942, Bachhulal filed suit for partition against Govindram and obtained decree; property divided, including Sugar Mills.
After partition, Govindram and Bachhulal jointly worked the Sugar Mills.
On September 28, 1943, Nandlal (son of Govindram) and Bachhulal, as kartas of their joint families, entered into partnership deed to carry on Sugar Mills business.

Partnership deed clause 3: 'The death of any of the parties shall not dissolve the partnership and either the legal heir or nominee of the deceased partner shall take his place in the provision of the partnership'.

Nandlal died on December 9, 1945, leaving three widows and two minor sons (Venkatlal b. 13-12-1931, Madanlal b. 25-1-1935? Wait, genealogy: minors Shantibai? Wait, text: members of his branch: three widows and two minor sons.
After Nandlal's death, Bachhulal carried on business in name of Seth Govindram Sugar Mills.
For assessment year 1950-51 (accounting year ending 31-3-1950?), firm applied for registration based on 1943 deed; ITO refused, treated as AOP.
Appeals to AAC dismissed; AAC held no partnership after Nandlal's death.
Tribunal dismissed appeals (ITA 8328/8329 of 1957-58).
High Court directed reference under s.66(2) Income-tax Act 1922: two questions on status as firm or AOP for 1950-51, and Tribunal error.
High Court held: status firm u/s 16(1)(b) for assessment year 1950-51? Text notes 1949-50 but context 1950-51; Tribunal erred.
After Nandlal death, Banarsibai and Shantibai applied to Jaora District Court for guardians; on Jan 21, 1946, four others appointed guardians of minors.
Accounts showed Kalooram Govindram and Gangaprasad Bachhulal as partners (10:6 annas); no name of Banarsibai; balances as on 1-11-1948 and closed 31-3-1950.
Oct 4, 1952: Partnership deed between Bachhulal and minors via four guardians.
March 27, 1953: Partnership deed between Venkatlal (via guardians) and Bachhulal.
Venkatlal attained majority on Dec 13, 1949 (born 13-12-1931).
Oct 17, 1951: Application for registration signed by Venkatlal and Bachhulal as partners representing families.
Return signed by Venkatlal on Aug 29, 1951.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the death of Nandlal (one of two partners), the partnership was dissolved under s.42 Partnership Act, despite clause 3 of deed.
Whether after Nandlal's death, a new partnership existed between representatives of the two families until Venkatlal's majority.
Status of assessee for assessment year 1950-51: firm u/s 16(1)(b) Income-tax Act or AOP.
Whether widow can be karta of joint Hindu family with minor sons.

petitioner_arguments.text: On death of Nandlal, firm dissolved u/s 42 Partnership Act; applies even to two partners; no automatic induction of heirs; thereafter AOP.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Partnership Act 1932 s.42; s.4, s.5

petitioner_arguments.text: No new partnership; no deed; conduct shows Bachhulal alone; widows not karta; guardians not partners.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law on karta; joint family cannot partner but karta can

respondent_arguments.text: Clause 3 overrides s.42; death does not dissolve; heirs automatically inducted; s.31 allows introduction without consent if contracted.
Partnership inferred from conduct and accounts post-death.

court_reasoning.text: Partnership arises from contract not status (s.4,5); s.42(c) applies to firms with >2 partners; for 2 partners, death dissolves automatically; no scope for heir induction without new contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fundamental principle: partnership from contract, not status.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected respondent: s.31 presupposes subsisting partnership; no interregnum but death ends 2-partner firm.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Heirs do not automatically become partners.

court_reasoning.text: Widow cannot be karta; coparcenership required; females not coparceners.
No evidence of new partnership post-death until Venkatlal majority; accounts show old names, no Banarsibai; conduct inconsistent (applied for guardians).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Partnership from Dec 13, 1949 when Venkatlal major and signed docs.

holdings.text: Partnership between Nandlal and Bachhulal dissolved on Nandlal's death Dec 9, 1945.
No partnership between family representatives until Dec 13, 1949; thereafter yes, with Venkatlal as karta.
For 1950-51, status is firm u/s 16(1)(b) Income-tax Act.
Widow not karta of joint family with minor coparceners.

Death dissolves 2-partner firm; no contract can continue it; heir needs consent.
Death ends 2-partner firm; legal reps form new if join later.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; partnership dissolved on Nandlal's death 1945; no new partnership until Venkatlal attained majority Dec 13, 1949; for 1950-51, assessee is firm u/s 16(1)(b); answers to questions in favor of assessee.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court judgment upheld on status as firm for 1950-51

key_quotes.text: "Partnership, under s. 4 of the Partnership Act, is the relation between persons who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all. Section 5 of the said Act says that the relation of partnership arises from contract and not from status."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Fundamental principle rejecting automatic heir succession.

key_quotes.text: "In the case of a partnership consisting of only two partners, no partnership remains on the death of one of them and, therefore, it is a contradiction in terms to say that there can be a contract between two partners to the effect that on the death of one of them the partnership will not be dissolved but will continue."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting Agarwala J. on why clause 3 invalid for 2-partner firm.

key_quotes.text: "Coparcenership is a necessary qualification for managership of a joint Hindu family."
key_quotes.speaker: court
